TBH I don't find this spec to be super clear how this is supposed to work.

This is my understanding, please let me know if it is incorrect:

  1. End user calls Nova API get_vnc_console for their baremetal instance
  2. Nova calls Ironic API get_console in the Ironic driver to get a url to hand back to the end user
  3. Ironic replies with a url that points at its own console proxy
  4. Nova replies to the end user with the Ironic console proxy url
  5. End user visits the url to the Ironic console proxy and all further actions take place in Ironic. The Nova console proxy will not be used at all for Ironic VNC consoles
The Nova console proxy will work with such vnc connection as usual. Ironic console proxy will be responsible for vnc handshake. we don't want provide to Nova a vnc password.

You've a long road to go here but watching with interest.

That problem is really that all those mixin classes use attributes that are defined in other places and type checkers cannot understand them really.

I started this as part of my work on replacing neutronclient with openstacksdk in Octavia. I use PyCharm and the experience as a user of openstacksdk there is just so much better with these type annotations. Without them I constantly need to jump between files.

The best thing about typing in Python is that it can make a huge difference even if you put annotations on a few things only. I might add a few more things to the network part since I'm working on that currently, but in general I don't intend to add much more annotations there right now.

One suggestion for the future that I have for the team is to move from type documentation in docstrings to these "real" typing annotations. They are without doubt much more powerful. The use of generic types in this patch demonstrate that really well.
Looks like a good start to me.
Yeah, good enough start.

octavia/controller/worker/flows/amphora_.message:
When an amphora gets *re*created (that is *not* using a spare-amp) we have an issue with this code, since the role in that case is set to ROLE_STANDALONE. 

This means that we will never use the multi-az-requirement when recreating amps. This was the issue I was hitting when commenting on this patch earlier, you can see the logs here http://paste.openstack.org/show/728729/ 

So what happens is that the log message I was referring to is actually *only* from the "flow" when looking for spare-amps, *but when* we don't have any spare-amps, and we get to L394, we specifically call the function ' get_amphora_for_lb_subflow' without any role set (it's commented in the code that it will be updated at a later point) which will make it default to ROLE_STANDALONE and thus this section wont have any affect. 

Since I'm not to familiar with the code, I'm not really sure what the proper workaround would be (either call the function with the correct role set (but I assume its unknown at that point since its not there to begin with), or change this part of the code). 

The way I solved it was to just add 'constants.ROLE_STANDALONE' to this if-statement. Not really sure if that will have any side-effects yet, but I can confirm that the code works as intended now. 

Amp's are properly being placed in separate az's, both at "creation" and "recreation".   

Took me quite a while to figure this one out - anyways, great job with this patch!

Yeah, thought about it a bit and I *hate* saying this, but the complexity in these flows is such that I think fixing the real issue (the fact that L394 just ignores the passed role) is probably more dangerous/disruptive than just letting the AZ code run on any type of amp. So, even though this is not something I will ever run into (since I use a spares pool -- highly recommended) I will just make that correction here and it should be fine.

There is a case if we change the configured AZs from "A,B,C" to "A,B". The dict which use for counting in L409, is based on the configured AZs, but we count by amp's db records. So if we had lauched a loadbalancer before we change from "A,B,C" to "A,B", and a amp in C for this loadbalancer. How we treat this case? Maybe using the failover mechisim? delete the amp in C?

elements/cpu-pinning/environment.d/80-ke.message:
Just to make sure: I read on RH downstream docs that the nohz parameter is required to activate the nohz_full parameter.

https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux_for_real_time/9/html/optimizing_rhel_9_for_real_time_for_low_latency_operation/con_isolating-cpus-using-the-nohz-and-nohz_full-parameters_optimizing-rhel9-for-real-time-for-low-latency-operation

So I am just adding this comment to make sure it was checked, I didn't test the feature yet and I am on PTO for a week from tomorrow.

The official Linux kernel documentation [1] says that nohz=on is the default, but I found no way to verify this at runtime. Fact is that in CentOS Stream 9 kernels CONFIG_NO_HZ_IDLE is not set and hence nohz might indeed not be active. Thanks for bringing this up.

I was unsure if I should include this setting at all in this change. I added it because it makes sense to me as it moves as much kernel noise away from isolated CPUs as possible and should reduce latency. However, I am not sure if it is really worth it and it goes beyond the original scope of this RFE.

That said, and given the fact that there isn't a lot time left for integrating this into the Zed release, I decided to move nohz_full stuff to a separate change so it can be tested and reviewed independently.

I only tested this change in my devstack environment so far, and when testing with nested VMs on a single host the performance results may differ a lot from a real production deployment. Hence I didn't post any measurement so far. However, I think that nohz_full in particular needs to be stress tested before it gets merged.

[1] https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/admin-guide/kernel-parameters.html?highlight=nohz

Updating the volume quota is a two-step process.
At the start of the operation, a preliminary quota reservation is created, which prevents cinder from exceeding the quota through parallel operations.
Depending on the success of the operation, the reservation will be either committed and made permanent, or rolled back.

The call to nova should happen after the reservation is created but before it is committed.

Cinder has the "extending" volume-state, which will be set until the extend operation is finished.

If we set the new size in the database, we still have to keep the the original size around somewhere (e.g. in the metadata) to be able to roll it back.
I should add this to the Alternatives section.

I do believe that updating the size in the database before the operation has successfully finished is a bad idea, though.
The size may not be rolled back if either of the services fail during the operation, and while Cinder has an API for resetting the volume state, there is currently no way of resetting the size, so we would need to introduce a mechanism for that.
It would also have an impact on metering, because Ceilometer will poll the size of the volume regardless of it's state.

Cinder will always try first to resize the file with qemu-img, even on attached volumes.
This is because volumes are only locked when attached to running instances, when the instance is shelved or shut off, qemu-img will work fine.

If qemu-img returns an error indicating that the file is locked, then Cinder should call assisted-volume-extend.
To my knowledge this will currently only happen when libvirt/qemu is in use.

But even if some other hypervisor was causing it, as long as the image is locked I see little harm in trying to call assisted-volume-extend regardless of the used virt driver.
In the worst case it will fail, but the operation would have failed anyway.
In the best case the virt driver actually implements assisted-volume-extend and performs a successful extend.
this only need to be avoided if the state is not change to reflect that the volume is current extending or pending extention

As mentioned above on #46, the state will be "extending", but I still believe we should avoid this.

"Synchronously" here concerns me. How long could a volume extend potentially take? I'm thinking of large volumes, certain disk formats, other? It doesn't seem like the sort of operation that services handle synchronously in general.

Looking at the cinder API ref, it looks like there isn't a way for nova to asynchronously let cinder know the result of the extend. Is that the reasoning for not making it asynchronous?

Just trying to think through whether this is going to bite us.

Well, the concern came from Cinder as well, although they agreed that the qemu block-resize operation should in realistic conditions be fast enough for a synchronous API.

An asynchronous API introduces more complexity and more possible error states, that was my original reason for proposing a synchronous API.

I agree that polling sounds like the least desirable way.

A synchronous API looked like the least complex solution.

But as I said above, I'm not opposed to an async solution.

The callbacks mentioned are pretty different from each other, so they didn't really feel like an established pattern:

os-update_snapshot_status just updates the status of the new snapshot, while the handler of the original create snapshot request keeps polling internally for this status change, so that it can continue and finalize the request or deal with errors.

os-migrate_volume_completion in contrast does all the cleanup itself, but has to infer information about the previous state from the volume object.

The second option is probably cleaner, but for assisted extend would require some temporary data to be stored in the volume object (such as the handle of the preleminary quota reservation), to do a proper rollback on error.

IIUC from the current spec text, the extend will be quick as long as the file is sparse. In cinder configuration, I see several config options <backend>_sparsed_volumes [1] which can be set to False, though they appear to all default to True. Are we confident that no one sets these to False? I don't know enough about storage config to know when not using sparsed files would be desired. The option help texts say "creation may take a significantly longer time" but creation is async. Excerpt from [1]:

 # Create volumes as sparsed files which take no space. If set to False volume
 # is created as regular file. In such case volume creation takes a lot of time.
 # (boolean value)
 #nfs_sparsed_volumes = true

 [...]

 # Create volumes as sparse files which take no space. If set to False, volume
 # is created as regular file. (boolean value)
 #quobyte_sparsed_volumes = true

Another thing I'm not 100% clear on, the spec says that cinder will only call the /os-assisted-volume-extend API if it hits the error from the QEMU lock and we only expect that to happen with NFS or Quobyte. There is a Long list of volume backends [2] and we know that there aren't any others that would end up needing to call the /os-assisted-volume-extend API that we should consider whether they are sparse? Should we think about the possibility of a future volume backend that may not be fast in extending an attached volume?

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/configuration/block-storage/samples/cinder.conf.html
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/configuration/block-storage/volume-drivers.html

The qemu block-resize command is hardcoded to extend sparsely, so this is independent of these options.
The main concerns with qemu are file systems without sparse support (which are rarely used), and fs errors that slow down the operation (someone mentioned NFS errors in the Cinder meeting).

Other virt/volume driver combinations using the API for slow operations is a potential concern, but right now I'm not aware of any that might want to.

specs/2023.1/approved/privsep-usage-revi.message:
no they profiels should be defiend in the root of the nova module

each profile quires a diffent privsep deamon ot handel it and having them per modules would signifcantly increae the memory usage of nova.

teh function that are privaldated should be in teh diffent moduels that use them

with common code shared but not marked as privaladged.
I see. I have rewritten the paragraph to reflect this. Please, take a look.

this is not really a performance impact

thsi is a correctness requiremnt and we wont be able to merge the new code until it works correclty.

our privsep usage and the capablity uses is not a configuration point for an operator so the only way for this to be mapped incorrectly is if the code is broken.

All right, I have removed the line then. 

I had my doubts on it too, but just to make sure I ended up making the comment.

technially is is not correct we dont aquire root rights. we span a deamon that has elevated privlages but we use the linux Capablities framework to restrict what those are.

rootwarp was the predicseoor that was full root but restricted to a set of predetermins commands.

those are two very different security models.
I have replaced it for 'acquiring capabilities' then. I believe it fits better now.

we cannot do this

each privsep context maps to an instance of the privsep deamon
that consume memory so while we can have a few context we cant have many contexts

if we have a funtion that need both netadmin and sysadmin that shoudl ideally be seperated into two functions.

if it cant be then teh current context that provides the system network and file capablities shoudl be used until we can come up with a better solution.


currenlty we have 1 context for nova. after this spec we shoudl have 4 but no more then that.
I have adapted the paragraph to your comments and also added another one detailing that we are limited in the number of profiles.

that not quite how it should work.


we shoudld have generic functions with wide contracts that are not privileged.
and specific function with narrow contracts that are privileged.

e.g.

def write_file(path,data, mode): 
  # unprivladged function that can wite any data to any location if the current user has permission to do so
  ...
  
def chown(path, user_group_string)
  os.chown(path, user_group_string)
  
@privsep_file_context
def privileged_write_tpm_data(instance_uuid:uuid,data:string)
   if not util.is_uuid(instnace_uuid):
     raise ValueError("the instance uuid is not a valid uuid")
   path = os.path.join(CONF.instance_state,instance_uuid,"tpm_data.txt")
   write_file(path,data,600)
   chown(path,"qemu:qemu")
   
   
write_file has a broad contract becuase it can take any path and any data or mode
privladged_write_tpm_data has a narrow contract because it only accpts the minium input that is reqoured for ti to work. in this case the instance uuid and the tpm data

Current usage of Privsep by Nova follow the best practices that was recommended by
the privsep lib when it was first created. 1 create a dedicated module for privladed function, 2 create a single context and restrict its usage to that module, 3 
limit the scope of privileged functions and reuse them form non privaded code.

Based on usage of the lib over they years it has become clear that this approach is
neither secure or desirable to continue. In the current design a single permission profile is shared by all functions that make use of the library, and this one aggregates all capabilities required by the entirety of privileged functions.

This means that because of a function that operates over files, another
one that does nothing over them will get rights over the filesystem as their
profile is shared. This may lead to unexpected behaviors on the system that
can be avoided if just enough capabilities are used on each case.

Privsep profiles will be defiend in https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/__init__.py

```
legacy_pctxt = priv_context.PrivContext(
    'nova',
    cfg_section='nova_sys_admin',
    pypath=__name__ + '.legacy_pctxt',
    capabilities=[capabilities.CAP_CHOWN,
                  capabilities.CAP_DAC_OVERRIDE,
                  capabilities.CAP_DAC_READ_SEARCH,
                  capabilities.CAP_FOWNER,
                  capabilities.CAP_NET_ADMIN,
                  capabilities.CAP_SYS_ADMIN],
)

sys_admin_pctxt = priv_context.PrivContext(
    'nova',
    cfg_section='privsep_sys_admin',
    pypath=__name__ + '.sys_admin_pctxt',
    capabilities=[capabilities.CAP_SYS_ADMIN],
)

net_admin_pctxt = priv_context.PrivContext(
    'nova',
    cfg_section='privsep_net_admin',
    pypath=__name__ + '.net_admin_pctxt',
    capabilities=[capabilities.CAP_NET_ADMIN],
)

file_admin_pctxt = priv_context.PrivContext(
    'nova',
    cfg_section='privsep_file_admin',
    pypath=__name__ + '.file_admin_pctxt',
    capabilities=[capabilities.CAP_CHOWN,
                  capabilities.CAP_DAC_OVERRIDE,
                  capabilities.CAP_DAC_READ_SEARCH,
                  capabilities.CAP_FOWNER],
)
```

For the sake of improving usability, shared code found across the package's
functions should be extracted into their own, unprivileged functions with broad

Technically, they should no longer reside into the nova.privsep package, but for an interim period of time, we could let them be there.

When elevated permissions are required, specialized single use functions with a narrow contract will be defiled using one of the new presep contexts.
These functions will be defined in the module that uses them and will contain privileged in the name. Privaldaged function should only be used in a single module and only be imported in unit tests.

I believe the idea is to restrict the scope on privileged functions as much as possible. We have already talked about extracting common functionality into general-use functions and have privileged ones be dedicated to very specific cases. This point tries to reduce their usage to a minimum. However, I do not know how feasible this will be on practice, meaning it will probably be a best practice to follow as much as we can.

Thanks for the explanation. I'm wondering that it might worth to enforce this via hacking somehow. We can probably detect the privsep decorated functions from hacking and then we would need to ensure that the decorated function is not mentioned outside of its module or in the unit test tree. However that second part needs a second pass on the codebase by hacking so might not be easy to implement. Alternatively we can think about a dynamic check instead of a static hacking check. In our unit / functional test env we could wrap the privsep decorator to inject a selective poison before the decorated function that could raise if the original function is called outside of the module it is defined or from the unit test tree. This is not trivial but probably doable with some decorator and inspect magic. Anyhow this is not affecting the spec itself just wanted to plant the seeds of automating this into your heads :)

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
It's true that this patch "saves" the user from hitting the duplicate resource problem if they neglect to assign a unique CinderNetappNfsSharesConfig per backend. But there will be other deployment failures if the user neglects to properly configure all the settings for their multi_config backends.

I guess I'm OK with the intent behind this patch, but it's ultimately the user's responsibility to provide an accurate set of parameters for their deployment. This patch may help avoid 1 issue, but there are probably 99 other ways a user can trip up.

A problem specific to the nfs_shares_config parameter is that the parameter can trigger puppet error which is not very quite clear to users. I agree this does not solve the all use cases, but would save users from "unkown" deployment failures.

Also, the parameter does not depend on deployment architecture and can easily determined automatically. That's another reason I try to solve the problem inside TripleO.

This is not a valid concern. Without going into a lot of technical background details, due to the tight coupling between cinder's NFS and NetApp backends, a user may have one or the other, but it would be unreasonable to have both.
Mixing NetApp + generic NFS might be rare but is valid, so I tend to leave this documented in commit message for future reference, in case anybody tries this set up and hit the same issue.

We have automation that can link up the bug and update its status and such if you specified the bug reference in the "body" of the commit message, like this: 

 Closes-Bug: #1989817
 
 
Let the first line of the commit message be ~50 characters, while you're being as clear as possible -- so when someone is reading the summary of commit messages on this repositories, they get the intent without having to dig deeper... 

So perhaps:

 "Fix formatting of OSC server migration check-only"
 
or something along those lines. 

You can add any further details in the commit message's body. Separate the Main commit line and its body by a blank line.. something along these lines:

 Fix formatting of OSC server migration check-only
 
 When the default table formatting is used, we can improve
 readability by transforming the capabilities dictionaries
 into paragraphs.
 
 Closes-Bug: #1989817
 

If you're interested in reading more about these commit message conventions, here's the long form: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages 😊 
And from our own developer docs: https://docs.openstack.org/manila/latest/contributor/commit_message_tags.html

Probably you should do 'if ver is None'  

The reason I suggest this is because if 'ver' was ever set to 0  (extremely unlikely) that would evaluate the same way as 'False' or None

I am wondering about the return.  Do you have code somewhere else that logs to indicate that the list being removed are no good?

I am also wondering if we want to (eventually) allow remove for mis-matched versions.  
ie: sort also by version.  All the ver=X  get listed before ver=X+1

but if we decide to do that, it would require an extra loop in the dependency code below.
I saw later in the code you have the None check (line 1262)
I like that you are able to make use of get_patch_dependency_list

I think it is OK to have this restriction, because a customer can simply remove all of versionX  and then versionY in a separate call. 

Orchestration could (down the road) try to remove a for multiple versions, if it thinks doing so will 'align' something like a subcloud with the system controller.
So we should keep mismatched remove on the radar as a feature to implement, if we choose to disable that here.
could result in TypeError if patch_remove_order is None and attempt to + to list.

patch_remove_order can never be None since all Debian patches are sequential. If we only have one patch, it would be handled by line 1222 and if we have more than one patch, we would always have at least one patch in "dependency_list", and consequently "patch_remove_order".

OK.  so the patch_length = 1 on line 1223 means that we can be guaranteed that at least 2 patches will be in the list when you get to the for loop, and therefore at least one of them will have a dependency, and therefore set the patch_remove_order value.

Based on the current implementation, what you have is fine.  But you can see that in the future, if you end up with sublists (ie: multiple version of patches) you might have scenarios where you have 2 patches that are not dependent on each other

I think what you have now is fine given the caveat that we only allow remove for a single patch version at a time.

I think it would be worthwhile to mention that:

contrary to how AgentDeploy gets the clean steps (via querying the agent ramdisk), AgentRAID's clean steps are known: create-configuration & delete-configuration. If the agent ramdisk does not support these two clean steps, the cleaning operation will fail if  they are enabled or if the target_raid_config is set.

Well I thought about it.  The problem is that they will not be able to run delete_configuration for the first time as node.raid_config is populated only after raid configuration is done once.  So in effect, delete_configuration won't run for the first time.  

How about skipping if both node.target_raid_config and node.raid_config are empty. Please see next patch set.
please use _LI()
Done

Some thoughts here...

1) Do we want to have these steps disabled by default in the future? I wonder because if we add it like this now it's not desirable to be changed later or we might mess up with someone's workflow here and break them.

...

2) Another thing I have in mind is the software vs hardware RAID that options will enable and disable. By reading the spec this interface should support both types of RAID correct?

So I wonder if a global configuration option is the right way to do it. Because, for the software RAID we have to recreate it after erasing the disks (since we are just zeroing all the devices we find locally). But for hardware RAID it's not very desirable to delete and recreate it every time the node goes trough cleaning, and, the way Ironic is architect we could have different drivers using both software and hardware raid at the same time.

What you think? Should we be able to differentiate those types of RAID and enable each one individually? Should the interface we have right now be the same for both types?

Please let me know your thoughts on it.

@Jim, I think it does.

re 2), assuming you have software and hardware RAID for different drivers and you have both drivers enabled in your cloud I think you will always want to have RAID configuration enabled for the software RAID as part of cleaning (but not for hardware RAID). Otherwise, one will create the software RAID as part of the Zapping then he/she move it to available state and passing trough cleaning it will erase all the local disks deleting the software RAID.

But, yeah we should move one. The spec mentions that the interface could potentially be used to create software RAID but it's not part of the scope of the spec [1]

[1] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/ironic-specs/specs/approved/inband-raid-configuration.html#proposed-change

Software RAID is something that we have discussed, but nobody has put a good enough investigation on it.  Yes, it should be possible to do software raid with the same interface, but I don't know it for sure.

The main reason why I wanted to have steps disabled by default is because RAID is truly optional.  The majority of users using Ironic might not even use it. So why not, just ask people to enable it if/when they want it.  I think it should be that way even for software RAID (even if we have software RAID supported in generic hardware manager) and it shouldn't be enabled by default unless people desire it

So in short, I think we should be able to support both types, but we don't know for sure.  Hence we shouldn't make any distinction right now and just go by what we know now.

Yeah, I'm okay with this code, for the following reasons:

1. We'll never enable this by default. RAID should always be opt-in since not all hardware supports it, and target_raid_config needs to be set manually anyway.

2. I don't think enabling only certain types of RAID makes sense; this can be done by changing the node's target_raid_config if need be.

I know we had a bit of a discussion about get_clean_steps(). I see you're using the base version, with the base.clean_step() decorators.

Which means that we don't go to IPA to see what/if it supports RAID, but it will assume that create_configuration() & delete_configuration() are available in the IPA ramdisk if someone configures the priorities to be non-zero.

Are we OK with AgentDeploy getting the clean steps from the ramdisk, but AgentRAID not? It is inconsistent but I don't know whether it should be consistent or not.

I'm not sure I agree because either way (with @base.clean_step or without) there will be issues and I'm concerned about the discrepancy wrt how we are handling/getting clean steps via the agent. AgentDeploy and AgentRAID behave differently now :-(

Having said that, I haven't sat down to itemize all the pros/cons for each method.

Yes, this seemed a better alternative because it keeps the user informed if someone set node.target_raid_config but agent doesn't support RAID. If operator provided node.target_raid_config but agent ramdisk didn't have such a method, node will be moved to CLEANFAIL with the following message:

  2015-09-21 19:21:13.176 ERROR ironic.drivers.modules.agent_base_vendor 
  [-] Agent returned error for clean step {u'priority': 20, u'interface': 
  u'raid', u'step': u'delete_configuration'} on node 
  169f5a78-1405-405c-b9c7-c82b627a22fd : {u'message': u'Clean step failed: 
  Error performing clean_step delete_configuration: No HardwareManager found to 
  handle method: Could not find method: delete_configuration', u'code': 500, 
  u'type': u'CleaningError', u'details': u'Error performing clean_step 
  delete_configuration: No HardwareManager found to handle method: Could not 
  find method: delete_configuration'}.


If rather we were not using @base.clean_step and we implemented our own get_clean_steps() like the AgentDeploy, then it would never get executed and we won't be able to inform users that raid config was never done.

I think we can move one with this since the spec mentions software raid but it explicitly says that it's out of the scope there. Tho I still believe that a differentiation for both types as part of the CLEANING should be done.

And, one more thing about the names of this configuration options, should it mention "cleaning" ? Otherwise once the raid configuration for zapping gets introduced how we are going to call the configuration option to set the priority there?

Well, I think I just named it like agent_erase_devices_priority above.  Since agent_ prefix seemed duplicate just removed it off.

iLO driver has priorities like cleaning_*,.  If'/When the raid configuration gets introduced as part of zapping, I think it doesn't matter and people needn't do any change here - because zapping doesn't demand the clean step to have a specific priority.  Any clean step can be invoked as a zap step. 

Do you meant something like create_raid_config_cleaning_priority and delete_raid_config_cleaning_priority

Lucas has a good point. I don't think it is necessary to add some 'clean' string to the name of the config, but I think it would be helpful to put something in the help string. Someone could go through and make sure all the clean-step configs are described the same way. (Ie, in another patch:)

I see that erase_devices_priority has 'If set to 0, will not run during cleaning.' We could do something like s/Priority/Priority (of this clean step)/ or be even more verbose.
Done
Right, ok I think I understand zapping better now; in zapping we explicitly pass which steps we want it to execute, the steps are not ordered as they are in cleaning (by priority).

I thought we had this discussion before; how do you know if the operator meant for RAID not to be done, versus wanting RAID but forgetting to set target_raid_config?

I think that in the case of automated cleaning, if they enabled RAID, it is RAID for all nodes. We don't have a way (yet) to opt out of other clean steps -- we should come up with a mechanism to opt out if that's a feature we want. I don't think we should use the absence of target_raid_config to mean 'opt out'. If we DO want it to mean opt out, we should document it.

Right, same for delete_configuration(), say I have a RAID configuration for that node and just want to delete it, but if target_raid_config or raid_config is not set it will skip it. So I have to set it to something to be able to delete it.

Yeah, as we have discussed before RAID is optional.  RAID for all nodes might not be possible.  Not even all bare metals from the same vendor might support RAID.  So we should have a mechanism to opt out.

The other way to indicate an opt-out would be with some special value in node.target_raid_config or somewhere else (like in driver_info) if operator wants to skip RAID configuration.  But I am not sure if it's going to complicate things more.  Operator will need to do this for each and every bare metal that they don't consider RAID.

We can document the current behaviour.  Do we really need to take care of operator forgetting to put target RAID configuration for cleaning ?

I don't know if we need to take care of operator forgetting, but I would guess that some operator WILL forget (or not know) to specify target RAID, or their process fails and doesn't do it or ...

I am (sort of) fine if we use .target_raid_config as a way to opt out. What I'm not fine is that we didn't discuss/agree to that (or is that mentioned in the spec?). I want to be sure we/reviewers are aware of the behaviour.

If we use this for opting out, I don't know how we can take care of operators forgetting to set it. And if we decide in the future that we want to use it to determine whether operators forgot to set it, I don't know that it will be backwards compatible with this behaviour :-(
nit: else not needed here

continuing from comment at L575...

There's a problem skipping it here if not set, that goes:

1. Node doesn't have a RAID configuration

2. Tentant creates a RAID in-band (talking to ramesh it's possible and can be expected)

3. Once it goes trough cleaning, since "target_raid_config" nor "raid_config" is set on that node, so cleaning will skip it.

4. New tenant will have the RAID configuration from previous tenant.

So our goal is to keep ironic-images.filters and ironic-utils.filters under ironic repo, and ironic-lib.filters under ironic-lib repo.

I'm concerned that rootwrap configs are stored in different locations in ironic repo - /etc/ironic/rootwrap.d/, which is the right place and ironic-lib - /etc/rootwrap.d/.
When system packages are build files placed to the exact path as it is defined in the repo. By follow this logic files from ironic-lib should be placed to /etc/rootwrap.d/ which is not right. The [0] contains deb control files to build ironic debian packages. Inside archive there is file called ironic-common.install that defines copy rules when ironic-common package is installed.

Package management teams from various distros: Ubuntu, Debian, SuSe etc... Should update theirs control/spec files for ironic-lib to copy etc/ironic/rootwrap.d/* to /etc/ironic/rootwrap.d/ during package installation.

What we can do for now?

1. make a symlink etc/ironic/rootwrap.d/ to etc/rootwrap.d under ironic-lib repo.

2. Until deprecation period is passed keep both ironic and ironic-lib files. Copy files from ironic-lib in devstack.
cp -r $IRONICLIB_DIR/etc/rootwrap.d/ $IRONIC_CONF_DIR

3. When deprecation is passed just remove ironic-lib.filters file from ironic repo.

specs/approved/deploy-fail-to-active.rst.message: I cannot agree with this point. We can and should verify that no destructive actions have been done to the node. If we allow this literally, and a node fails while connected to the provisioning network, a user will be able to run their code on the provisioning network by powering the machine back on. This is a security hazard.

wrt downstream patch: yes, of course that is possible. The whole idea of this spec etc is to do something upstream (if upstream WANTS it) so that others can also use it.

wrt permit in maintenance mode: sure. What exactly though is the flow? Node is in 'deploy failed', admin puts in maintenance, admin issues X to put node in 'active', admin removes from maintenance?

wrt checking if IPA (or some other deploy driver) has started. Yes, this is do-able.

wrt recovery. I'd consider that outside the scope of this spec (eg phase 2), unless people feel like we can't do this without a recovery mechanism.

(One thing that bothers me, is that ironic doesn't actually keep info about the bm node wrt what it KNOWS about it. eg, ironic uses instance_info to deploy, but then that info could be changed and we don't know what was used for the actual deployment. I suppose if we had some audit trail, it could be figured out.)

Sure. I believe we mentioned this at the PTG when we discussed this feature. What verification do you suggest that we do in code? I was afraid of rabbit-holing here. Whatever we do, I still think we might want this caveat.

I looked at the nova 'equivalent' and it doesn't do any checking/validation.

This is explicitly an action designed for handling error cases. I don't think the security hazard argument necessarily applies to an admin action that overrides normal  Ironic behavior -- since the sheer need to run this would indicate a failure in Ironic.

Some basic sanity checking might be nice, but we should not force operators to perform drastic actions, or interact with the DB, to recover from a failure scenario. Today, that's not true for cases where Nova rebuilds fail in certain ways.

I see in the story, that Dmitry mentioned 'safe guards/recovery actions in this case (e.g. if we change the boot device DISK->PXE, we need to change it back, etc'

We should definitely discuss. I had briefly thought about this, but to do it well? means taking a 'snapshot' of the node's settings? before the rebuild happens. even the instance/image information could have changed during the rebuild. Dmitry is probably right, people will shoot themselves in the feet... hmm. this won't work. nova sets/updates the instance info before ironic does a rebuild, so ironic won't know to save any info before it does the rebuild unless ironic always backs up the instance info. Let's see how many people really want this feature and how hardened they want it to be...

A counter-statement: an operator who knows ironic so deeply to understand when it's safe or not is capable of a downstream patch. Or we can permit it in maintenance mode (as we do for some actions).

As a first step here we can check if IPA has started on the node (by the presence of temporary fields). This is probably good enough for most cases.

Then we have a question of recovery, which is actually more problematic. We need to restore: boot device, boot mode and secure boot status, as well as restore PXE configuration if the instance is network booting. This essentially calls for a new transient state ("restoring"?).

If we don't do recovery, we're pretty much doomed to leave a node in a state in which it won't survive the next reboot. I don't feel well creating a feature that only you and Jay can use reliably.

If it was an ironic-dbsync command, I would not object, but I guess you want to integrate it with nova?

Finally, I don't think we should account for the case "admin set instance_info to some non-sense".
I'd slightly prefer to use just "active" instead of inventing a new verb.

My concern with 'active' is due to the caveat I put above, about user-admin-beware. I wanted to be explicit that it was a 'reset of state' vs 'guaranteed, ironic is moving it to that state cuz ironic knows it is ok to be active'.

Another reason for not using 'active' is because 'active' is already used to move nodes in 'deploy failed' to 'deploying' [1]. I am not sure we should use the same verb to do two diff things depending on something else, although that is possible (the user would have to indicate that they want the node to be 'active' and skip deploying on the way there? Thoughts?

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/_images/states.svg

I doubt that it is impossible. It means engaging with nova etc. Which I don't plan on doing right now cuz I'm short of time :) Whatever we do to hook up with nova, I don't think the ironic API part would change.

Would you like me to reword it somehow? eg. 'It may be possible to have nova enhanced to call this new API, but that will not be done in this first phase' ?

.pre-commit-config.yaml.message: Remove and try to run "tox -epy3,functional,pep8" in push stage instead.

I ran a couple of tests. TL;DR: running tox seems way too slow IMO.

1. With flake8:

- repo: local
  hooks:
    - id: flake8
      name: flake8
      additional_dependencies:
        - hacking>=3.1.0,<3.2.0
      language: python
      entry: flake8
      files: '^.*\.py$'
      exclude: '^(doc|releasenotes|tools)/.*$'
      
$ time pre-commit run --all-files
flake8...................................................................Passed

real    0m8,312s
user    1m22,788s
sys     0m1,660s

2. With tox -epep8

- repo: local
  hooks:
    - id: tox
      name: tox -epep8 tests
      language: system
      entry: tox -epep8
      pass_filenames: false
      
$ time pre-commit run --all-files
tox -epep8 tests.........................................................Passed

real    1m10,875s
user    8m30,872s
sys     0m6,498s


As you see the difference is significant, and with tox it will always check all files even if they haven't been changed. In my test I've let flake8 check all files as well. In reality it would only run on files that were added to the commit. Hence I suggest we use the flake8 hook. Other openstack projects to the same.

Check how fast the flake8 hook is. If it really only checks modified files it should be very fast and then we might want to use it as pre-commit hook anyway. tox will always be slower as it works on all files.
See my other comment below. I'd say flake8 is fast enough to have it as pre-commit hook.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: LGTM, it doesn't cover everything that is done by the tox -epep8 checker, but I guess that's enough to prevent from pushing broken code.

Hey Balazs,
thank you for your patch ☺️

I only had time for a glimpse at the patch, not a proper reviews. Here are some notes:

* be consistent with other modules in style and coding. for example, modules with a '_will_change' method follow a similar structure which supports updates and idempotency. its worth to follow this style even if your module does not support updates yet

* if your module does not support updates, please mark attributes which cannot be updated, e.g. put '- This attribute cannot be updated.' into their description

* author must be OpenStack Ansible SIG, if this patch is completely written from scratch by you, then you can add your name to copyright comment at the beginning.

* always stick to attribute names from openstacksdk for module inputs and outputs

* use consistent names, e.g. not secgroup_rules vs security_group (former is abbreviated, latter is long form). in this case security_group_rules is more consistent with sdk and other modules.

* DOCUMENTATION is for users: use "simple" english, try to avoid abbreviations (e.g. 'NB'), move technical details about impl to code comments if it is not important for module usage

* drop try-except since it base class will handle sdk errors

* do not try to fix every user error, you will never be able to catch and fix them all. for example, you could drop _deduplicate_rules and let openstack raise an error, then users will fix their rules.

* if you get useable output from openstacksdk (e.g. from create_security_group_rules), then return it to the user

* remove dead code, e.g. old code im comments

To be continued.

We are adding one more for L3 module. Is all 3 parameters should have the same value or each module can have its own integration brdige?
